Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 09:15PM hazelfox36 wrote: I too have very dense breasts.  I am 38 years old and I was diagnosed with 5cm mass in my LB thatw turned out to be Invasive Ductal Carcinoma on Oct. 12th 2007.  I went through 6 cycles of taxotere and carboplatin.  After chemo all my scans(mammo, PET, MRI) came back no evidence of disease. I had a lumectomy on March 27th(dirty margins), another lumpectomy on April 24th (dirty margins) and finally I decided on a mastectomy on May 13th.  The best decision that I could have made because I had DCIS throughout my left breast, but now I wonder about my right because I only had a unilateral mast.  I had lymph node involvement so I have to have radiation after I am done healing from this last surgery.
Posts.Title: Read This if You Have Dense Breasts Aug242007 Aug242007

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2008 03:45AM hazelfox36 wrote: I had a lumpectomy on March 27, 2008, but unfortunately didn't get clear margins so in for a partial mastectomy on April 24, 2008....good luck with your surgery.
Posts.Title: Anyone having surgery in April?? ottawagirl wahine

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 09:01PM hazelfox36 wrote: dolphinsac.....When I had my surgery they did use the ultrasound to put the wires in.  I don't understand why they wouldn't do that.  It did not take them that long to use the ultrasound to insert the wires so maybe you could have the surgeon plan something ahead of time to use the ultrasound.  My surgeon did not do anything that I was uncomfortable with.  I didn't even know that they inserted wires with a mammo...I thought all them were done with ultrasound because that is the way it was done with me.  My thoughts and prayers are with you......
Posts.Title: Unable to commit to surgery dolphinsac pinoideae

Posts.Content: hazelfox36 wrote: I am really concerned about my pathology report.  I had a complete dissection of my axilliary lymph nodes when I had surgery and all they could find was one lymph node and that one tested positive.  I had chemotherapy before my surgery and all of my scans (mammogram, pet scan, and MRI) came back with no evidence of disease. My surgeon says that I really should not worry about it because she believes that the other lymph nodes that were involved when I was first diagnosed were likely destroyed by the cancer and the chemotherapy and just do not appear to look like lymph nodes anymore.  I was just wondering if anyone has had similar experiences with only one lymph node being found in a complete dissection...Thank you Dx 10/12/2007, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 3/4 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: after surgery pathology report hazelfox36 hazelfox36

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 02:02PM - edited May 27, 2008 02:03PM by hazelfox36 Nicole I am 38 and was diagnosed with IDC stage 2b on October 12th, 2007.  I am sure that the surgeon is letting you know the worst case scenario.  I went through 2 lumpectomies to remove my cancer and then had to have a mastectomy and did lose my nipple.  I am just 2 weeks out of the surgery and I am starting to accept it.  But just remember the surgeon has to let you know all the risks that come with your type of surgery. Just stay positive and don't let the maybes get the best of you.
Posts.Title: don't want to lose my nipple... help me Nicole22 tamc130

Posts.Content: hazelfox36 wrote: I had a unilateral modified radical mastectomy on May 13th.  I have two Jp drains.  I changed the dressing today and it looks like there is a little puss and drainage from the entrance of the drain.  It doesn't really hurt except for the drains being there themselves.  I have a post-op on Monday May 19th. Has anyone else experienced this, because with my first lumpectomy my drain was fine. Dx 10/12/2007, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 3/4 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: JP drain infection? hazelfox36 MsSherry

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2008 10:45PM hazelfox36 wrote: I go back to the oncologist in a couple weeks.  I will definitely mention it to her.. Just makes me so nervous wondering I guess after everything that has been done to me to help me get well...
Posts.Title: lumps under the skin after mastectomy hazelfox36 sassie62

Posts.Content: hazelfox36 wrote: It is 2 months since my third surgery, which was a mastectomy.  Now that I am pretty much healed from the last surgery I am feeling three lumps on my side where they removed breast tissue. They don't hurt, but I can't feel anything there anymore from my axillary dissection, so I was wondering if anyone else has experienced little lumps after their mastectomy? Dx 10/12/2007, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 3/4 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 01:42AM hazelfox36 wrote: Yes I have problems with yeast infections and antibiotics....My doctor gives me Keflex and that does not seem to cause me any of those nasty yeast infections. ,,,,,,,,,,tc...........Carrie
Posts.Title: Yeast Infections srissman lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: May 18, 2008 12:06AM hazelfox36 wrote: I just had a single modified radical mastectomy on May 13th.  You will definitely need some help.  My sister-in-law came over in the evenings when my husband had to go to work and would help me make dinner for the kids and things like that.  The best thing to do is if you can is to make meals ahead of time and freeze them so all you have to do is warm them up. I need some help changing the dressings at the drain sites also.  I am 38 and this whole thing has been a little difficult for me also.  Just stay as positive as you can and just do a little planning ahead of time and everything will be just fine.........Hugs

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2008 11:38AM - edited Jun 3, 2008 11:41AM by hazelfox36  Photogirl, I just had a mastectomy on May 13th.  I still have to have radiation.  I was told the reason I have to have radiation is because there could still be some small amounts left that are not detectable by pathology. I did have lymph nodes involvement also. I was also told if the the mass is  5cm or larger in size radiation is necessary.
